awd_titl_txt: Untangling the Energetics and Dynamics of Reactions of Ground State Silylidyne Radicals with Hydrocarbon Molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
With this renewal award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A Program (CSDM-A) of the Division of Chemistry supports Professor Ralf I. Kaiser of the University of Hawaii in a project that will investigate the mechanism and energetics of the reactions of a diatomic silicon species with hydrocarbon molecules. These experiments will be carried out by crossing beams of the reacting molecules in the gas phase and allowing them to interact. Experiments will be combined with sophisticated computational studies to provide mechanistic and thermodynamic data for these reactions. Since molecules containing silicon are important components of the interstellar environment, significant advances in our understanding of astrochemistry are predicted to result from this project. In connection with these studies, the principal investigator will organize symposia on interstellar and gas phase chemistry.
 
The proposed research will investigate the energetics, dynamics, and potential energy surfaces of the diatomic radical, silylidyne (SiH), with hydrocarbon molecules employing crossed molecular beam experiments. The data resulting from these experiments will be combined with ab initio and quasi classical trajectory (QCT) calculations to determine reaction mechanisms, the structure of products and intermediates and thermodynamics over a broad range of collision energies. These studies will enable a comparison of the chemical dynamics of the silylidyne radical (SiH) with those of the isoelectronic methylidyne radical (CH).
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The prime directive of our research project was to explore the energetics and fundamental reac-tion dynamics involved in the formation of silicon-bearing molecules under single collision con-ditions in the gas phase and to apply these finding to rationalize the synthesis of small (in)orga-nic, silicon-carrying molecules in interstellar and circumstellar environments. This required the development of novel supersonic radical sources, namely of ground state silylidyne radicals (SiH(X2Π)) generated via photolysis of helium-seeded disilane (Si2H6).


This radical beam was exploited to untangle the previously elusive dynamics of silylidyne radical reactions with a homologous series of hydrocarbons: alkynes, alkenes, and alkanes. Considering alkynes [acetylene (C2H2), methylacetylene (CH3CCH), dimethylacetylene (CH3CCCH3)], the detection of 1-silacycloprop-2-enylidene (SiC2H2; 2-methyl-1-silacycloprop-2-enylidene (SiC2HCH3), and 2,3-dimethyl-1-silacycloprop-2-enylidene (SiC2(CH3)2) manifested the formation of three representatives of the hitherto obscure class of (partially aromatic) organosilicon molecules: silacyclopropenylidenes). Note that crossed molecular beams reactions of the silylidyne radical with C2 to C4 alkanes and alkenes did not reveal any reactive scattering signal at collision energies up to 40 kJmol-1 due to significant entrance barriers (alkanes) and overall endoergic reactions (alkenes). However, hydrocarbons carrying carbon-carbon double bounds could ‘open up’ their reactivity, if the carbon-carbon double bond is either ‘cummulenic’ such as in allene (H2C CCH2) or in conjugation with a second carbon-carbon double bond (dienes) as found in 1,3-butadiene (H2CCHCHCH2). Crossed beam reactions of the silylidyne radical with allene and 1,3-butadiene revealed the formation of two cyclic products via indirect scattering dynamics, isomerization(s) of the initial collision complexes via hydrogen shifts and ring closure and atomic hydrogen loss in overall exoergic reactions: 2-methyl-1-silacycloprop-2-enyidene (SiC2H CH3) and 1-silacyclopenta-2,4-diene (SiC4H6), respectively. The reaction of silylidyne with D4-allene (D2CCCD2) provided evidence of two distinct mechanisms leading to 2-methyl-1-silacycloprop-2-enyidene (SiC2HCH3) involving hydrogen shifts and cyclization.


Further, we expanded our studies of silylidyne radical reactions to simple diatomic molecules: molecular oxygen (O2) in order to explore the formation of the simplest building block of interstellar silicates with the latter play a key role in star formation and in the origin of solar systems. Our research demonstrated via a combined crossed molecular beam and computational study that silicon dioxide (SiO2) along with silicon monoxide (SiO) can be synthesized via the reaction of the silylidyne radical (SiH) with molecular oxygen (O2) under single collision condi-tions. This mechanism may provide a low-temperature path - in addition to high-temperature routes to silicon oxides in circumstellar envelopes - possibly enabling the formation and growth of silicates in the interstellar medium necessary to offset the fast silicate destruction.


Finally, we investigated the reaction dynamics of the phenyl radical (C6H5; X2A’) with silane (SiH4) under single collision conditions revealing the formation of phenylsilane (C6H5SiH3) plus atomic hydrogen (H) via direct scattering dynamics through a single transition state involving a simultaneous silicon-carbon bond formation and a silicon-hydrogen bond rupture via a trigonal bipyramidal transition state. Compared to the isovalent methane (CH4) – phenyl radical (C6H5) system, the replacement of a single carbon atom by silicon lowers the barrier to substitution by about 130 kJmol-1 thus making the substitution pathway in the silane – phenyl system com-petitive with the hydrogen abstraction channel than in the methane – phenyl system, which only shows an abstraction to benzene (C6H6) plus methyl (CH3). Therefore, reactions with silicon-bearing species such as the doublet silylidyne radical as proposed here shed light on an unexplored silicon chemistry and hitherto unobserved chemical dynamics providing fundamental insights into novel reaction mechanisms via radical substitution pathways through transition states involving penta-coordinated silicon.


Also, during this project, we trained 14 scientists – among them Hawaiian and female scientists - in the fields of chemical dynamics. Our collaborative training involved well-reputed theoreti-cians (Head-Gordon, UC Berkeley; Chang, National Dong Hwa University, Taiwan; Stanton, Texas; Bauschlicher, NASA Ames) demonstrating our commitment to train scientists capable of assuming leading roles in US science in the future. Further, we organized the ACS symposia ‘Biochemistry in Extreme Environments’ and ‘Expanding the frontiers in condensed phase astrochemistry: electron transfer processes in ices and catalysis on interstellar grains’ at the Fall (2014) and Spring (2017) ACS meetings along with the ‘Laboratory Astrophysics Workshop’ in Kauai (2015). These meetings were immensely successful in attracting young (60 %) and female (30 %) scientists to the lectures.


Last Modified: 07/06/2018
Modified by: Ralf I Kaiser
